title: Medically Assisted Reproduction: The Effects on Children, Adults and Families
descriptions:
Here is a 294-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Medically Assisted Reproduction: The Effects on Children, Adults, and Families

The increasing trend of Medically Assisted Reproduction (MAR) treatments over the last four decades has resulted in more than five million MAR-conceived children born worldwide. Despite this growing phenomenon, the effects of MAR on family well-being remain a significant public health prerogative. Previous research has yielded mixed results, limited by low statistical power and conceptual limitations. This project aims to address these gaps by conducting a comprehensive analysis of the effects of MAR on children, adults, and families.

Using a multi-faceted research approach, we will employ innovative research designs to establish causality and compare outcomes across different life domains. Leveraging population registers and surveys, we will analyze physical health, mental health, education, and union stability outcomes in MAR-conceived individuals and their families. Our research design includes sibling comparisons of MAR-conceived vs. spontaneously conceived individuals, as well as adult comparisons of successful MAR conception vs. unsuccessful attempts.

This project has the potential to yield ground-breaking results, inform future research, and have important policy implications. The findings will benefit health professionals, public health authorities, and policy-makers, informing health advising, resource allocation, and MAR treatment subsidies. By providing a comprehensive understanding of the effects of MAR, this project will ultimately contribute to the well-being of families and individuals involved in MAR treatments.

Here is a possible abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Medically Assisted Reproduction: The Effects on Children, Adults, and Families

The increasing trend of Medically Assisted Reproduction (MAR) treatments has resulted in over five million children born through this method in the last four decades. Despite its growing popularity, the effects of MAR on family well-being remain poorly understood. Previous studies have yielded mixed results, limited by low statistical power and conceptual limitations. This project aims to fill this knowledge gap by conducting a comprehensive analysis of the effects of MAR on children, adults, and families. Using innovative research designs, population registers, and surveys, we will compare MAR-conceived individuals with spontaneously conceived siblings and adults who have undergone successful or unsuccessful MAR treatments. Our study will examine a range of outcomes, including physical and mental health, education, and union stability. The expected ground-breaking results will have important policy implications for health advising, resource allocation, and MAR treatment subsidies, ultimately benefiting health professionals, public health authorities, and policy-makers. By shedding light on the effects of MAR, this project will inform evidence-based policies and practices that promote the well-being of families and individuals involved in MAR.

Here is an abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Medically Assisted Reproduction: The Effects on Children, Adults, and Families

The increasing number of Medically Assisted Reproduction (MAR) treatments over the last four decades has resulted in more than five million MAR-conceived children born worldwide. Despite this trend, the effects of MAR on family well-being remain a pressing public health prerogative. Previous studies have yielded mixed results, limited by low statistical power and conceptual limitations. This project aims to address these gaps through a comprehensive analysis of the effects of MAR on children, adults, and families. Using population registers and surveys, we will conduct a sibling comparison of MAR-conceived versus spontaneously conceived individuals, as well as an adult comparison of successful MAR conception versus unsuccessful attempts. Our innovative research designs will allow us to establish causality and examine outcomes across physical health, mental health, education, and union stability. This project has the potential to yield ground-breaking results, informing future research and policy decisions. The beneficiaries of this study will include health professionals, public health authorities, and policy-makers, ultimately influencing health advising, resource allocation, and MAR treatment subsidies.
